Award.AwardTitle: 2011-2016 Northeast Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (Senior Alliance Project)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Northeast LSAMP (NELSAMP) has significantly increased underrepresented minority (URM) enrollment in STEM baccalaureate disciplines and their graduation at five independent institutions located in three different states. The Alliance enables its institutions to implement best practices that ensure student success, such as research opportunities and formal Supplemental Instruction programs. It also provides opportunities for NELSAMP students from the five institutions to interact and find a larger identity group through Alliance-wide events.
The proposed NELSAMP Senior Alliance aims to maintain and build upon its existing programs, develop intentional pathways for student progression from community college STEM associate degree programs into NELSAMP, and implement an NELSAMP-specific international research experience for upper level students. In addition, it will encourage other NELSAMP students to participate in existing international research activities by providing travel support funds.
The intellectual merit of the NELSAMP Senior Alliance is reflected in several aspects of its work. NELSAMP will develop a cohort model to track and support URM community college students through their combined AS-BS sequence in STEM majors. Near-peer activities and participation in Alliance-wide events will improve student persistence during their community college years. The international research components will, similarly, add to STEM persistence in the third and fourth undergraduate years.
The broader impacts of this proposed NELSAMP Senior Alliance include the increased pipeline of students from URM populations in three states who persist from high school ?directly or through community college -to degree completion in baccalaureate STEM disciplines. In addition to buttressing persistence in STEM for upper level NELSAMP students, the success of a dedicated international research experience program in South Africa ? a country with many institutions eager to partner with Alliances- should serve as a model to expand dramatically the number of international opportunities for other LSAMP students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report 2011-2016

In 2001 the University of Massachusetts Amherst, the University of Connecticut, the University of Rhode Island, Northeastern University, and Worcester Polytechnic Institute formed the Northeast LSAMP (NE-LSAMP). The intent was to work as an alliance of public and private institutions to advance the goals of LSAMP chapters across the country: increasing enrollment, retention, and graduation rates of under-represented students (URM) in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines. As an alliance, NE-LSAMP leveraged the resources and extended the reach of each institution, supporting alliance-wide and campus-specific activities and initiatives.  During the five-year grant period, NE-LSAMP provided support to 300 students and realized increased URM enrollment at each institution, along with improved rates of retention and graduation. In addition, NE-LSAMP prepared students for graduate school and contributed to their successful matriculation into PhD programs. With NE-LSAMP alumni in graduate programs at research universities across the nation, the alliance is advancing LSAMP’s broad goal of long-term change in the nation’s production of PhDs from underrepresented populations and their entrance into academic research and/or professional careers.  In 2015 and 2016, ~25 students from NE-LSAMP applied to graduate programs and ~15 were accepted.  

NE-LSAMP employed a comprehensive approach to recruitment that included direct outreach to students prior to their freshman or transfer year, and involvement of STEM faculty, current LSAMP students, and administrators in ensuring new NE-LSAMP students are integrated into their institution and are quickly familiarized with the opportunities NE-LSAMP offers. To encourage persistence in the baccalaureate program, NE-LSAMP implemented proven interventions such as mentoring and undergraduate research experiences, and to these it added supplemental instruction in barrier courses, tutoring, one-credit or boot camp courses to orient students and develop strong cohorts, GRE preparation, and professional development. Working as an alliance, NE-LSAMP was able to provide a network of research and professional development opportunities for its students, allowing them, for example, to gain experience and confidence while working in different labs and with other faculty, or to present their research at the annual alliance-wide Poster Symposium. Through its partnership with COSEE-TEK, students at each campus formed teams to compete in a year-long challenge focused on marine sciences and engineering. Students also benefited from participation in academic conferences, specific to their area of study or, as with the GEM conference, to their pursuit of a graduate degree. Alliance-wide events provided opportunities for students from the five campuses to find common ground with a community of like-minded peers and to celebrate their achievements and aspirations.  

NE-LSAMP drew from its first ten years of success in designing and implementing its international research experience (IREU). Over five years, a total of 30 NE-LSAMP students participated in the IREU, traveling to universities in France or South Africa to engage in research projects. Students return from these experiences with improved research skills, results from the research that can be shared with other students, and with fresh ideas about the multiple opportunities for research, problem-solving, and knowledge production in their field of study. NE-LSAMP will continue to build on its successes and to inspire and prepare URM, STEM students for the academic and professional careers that allow them to realize their full potential and contribute at the highest levels to their communities.
